rComments: Charles brings it. He lectures well, has strong opinions that he can back up, and throws some perspective in to break up the dryness of textual course. Open about editorializing, has a modern outlook toward teaching. Debate champ, so make sure your arguments are sound, he responds to tough questions/assertions with an even stronger question

Olney, for the most part, explained the concepts clearly. Lectures were long, but not required. Had a midterm, 2 papers (second one was a revision of the first one, and a final. Reading was definitely doable compared to other legal studies/politics classes. Overall, this class was easier than expected.
He is very clear and goes over the readings. If you do the study guides you are set for the final. You need to do the readings.

Mr. Olney is very well spoken and his lectures are mostly oriented on him speaking. He knows what he is talking about and is passionate about it. His office hours tend to be completely open because students do not use them and they are helpful. I recommend walking with him to his office if you can if you want to leave an impression.
Makes the lectures seem very long because it is mostly him speaking. Would have liked it if there was a powerpoint with actual notes.

I took this class as I was contemplating the major, so I really knew little about the topic. It isn't exactly what I thought and is more theoretical based and based on viewpoints of the law. Nonetheless, an interesting class. Only 2 exams (midterm & final) and 2 essays (3 pages each). When asked for help, he's able to articulate the point well.

This was my first quarter at UCSC and taking this instructor really did remind me why I chose to come here. It's a lot of work taking his classes, but I learned an immense amount that I will take with me throughout my life. I was introduced to legal scholars and other thinkers while taking his classes that really challenged my world view.

Great professor, really knows his stuff. lectures can be kind of boring but he is always willing to help and answer questions so make sure you take advantage of that and go to his office hours. Can't really get away with not reading for the class. Tests/ quizzes are basically all about the readings.

Great teacher.  He's very sharp and knows his material.  He can debate his point, so if you want to contradict hit, you better know what you're talking about.  He is extremely knowledgeable on current issues.  His awareness of the law is impressive as well.  Pay attention and read because there is a lot of reading to keep up with him.

Went in with little to no expectations (since he didn't have a rate my professor account) and was pleasantly surprised. He knows a great deal about what he is teaching, lectures can be long because most of it consists of him lecturing at you with no visual aid but nonetheless he's a very fair grader. Discussions and reading are mandatory.
